{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} The '''1995–96 [[British Collegiate American Football League]] season''' was the 11th full season of the BCAFL, organised by the British Students American Football Association (BSAFA, now the [[British American Football Association|BAFA]]). No new teams were added in the 1995–96 season. {| class="infobox vevent" style="width:20em; font-size:90%;" cellspacing="2" |- !colspan="2" style="font-size:larger; text-align:center" class="summary" |40th Chess Olympiad |- |align="center" colspan="2" | [[File:Chess Olympiad 2012 official logo.jpg]]
Logo of the 40th Chess Olympiad |- !Dates run |27 August – 10 September 2012 |- !Competitors |1,407 |- !Teams |157 (Open)
127 (Women) |- !Nations |152 (Open)
122 (Women) |- !Venue |[[Istanbul Expo Center]] |- !Location |[[Yeşilköy]], [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Champions |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Team |- !Open |{{gold1}} {{ARM}}
{{silver2}} {{RUS}}
{{bronze3}} {{UKR}} |- !Women |{{gold1}} {{RUS}}
{{silver2}} {{CHN}}
{{bronze3}} {{UKR}} |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Individual |- !Open | {{flagicon|AZE}} [[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]] |- !Women |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Nadezhda Kosintseva]] |} The '''40th [[Chess Olympiad]]''', organised by the [[Fédération Internationale des Échecs]] and comprising an openAlthough commonly referred to as the ''men's division'', this section is open to all male and female players. and women's tournament, as well as several events designed to promote the game of [[chess]], took place in [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]],[http://www.chessdom.com/news/chess-olympiad-istanbul-2012 Chess Olympiad 2012 in Istanbul, Turkey], Chessdom.com. from 27 August to 10 September 2012. The city also hosted the [[34th Chess Olympiad|event in 2000]]. More than 1,700 players and team captains participated, including 157 teams in the open and 127 teams in the women's section.[http://www.chessdom.com/team-starting-rank-for-the-40th-world-chess-olympiad/ Team starting rank for the 40th World Chess Olympiad], Chessdom.com. The main competitive events were held at the [[Istanbul Expo Center]]. The Chief Arbiter of the event was [[Greece]]'s [[International Arbiter]] Panagiotis Nikolopoulos.[http://ratings.fide.com/tournament_details.phtml?event=69392 40th World Chess Olympiad-Open] FIDE Tournament Details[http://ratings.fide.com/tournament_details.phtml?event=69393 40th World Chess Olympiad-Women] FIDE Tournament Details == Background == Istanbul's hosting the [[34th Chess Olympiad]] in 2000 sparked a "Chess boom" in the country. Turkey has since hosted more than 100 international chess tournaments, including European Championships, World Youth Championships, and Youth Chess Olympiads. Membership in the Turkish Chess Federation has risen from 3,000 to about 250,000 in only eight years. [[Ali Nihat Yazıcı]], President of the [[Turkish Chess Federation]], is credited with triggering most of the activities towards this intensive chess development in the country.[http://www.chessvibes.com/reports/formal-protest-issued-against-turkish-chess-federation Formal protest issued against Turkish Chess Federation], Chessvibes.com, 11 June 2012. He was later elected a Vice-President of FIDE. Istanbul won the right to host the 40th Chess Olympiad in November 2008, during the 78th Congress of [[FIDE]] at the [[38th Chess Olympiad]] in [[Dresden]]. Istanbul's bid was approved by a vote of 95–40 over [[Budva]]. == The event == [[File:Olympiad2012Entrance1.jpg|thumb|The [[Istanbul Expo Center]], the location of the tournament]] === Competition format === The tournament was played in a [[Swiss-system tournament|Swiss system format]]. The [[time control]] for every single game was 90 minutes per 40 moves, with addition of 30 seconds per move, and 30 minutes after the 40th move. It was allowed once again for a player to offer a [[Draw by agreement|draw]] at any time during the game. A total of 11 rounds were played, in which every team played with four of their players against another team. Every team was allowed to nominate one reserve player.[http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook.html?id=95&view=article FIDE Handbook: Olympiad Pairing Rules], [[FIDE]]. Teams were ranked according to the match points won in every round. In case of same number of match points by one or more teams, the tie-breaker is decided by applying: 1. The [[Sonneborn-Berger]] system; 2. Total game points scored; 3. Sum of the match points of the opponents, excluding the lowest one. === Open event === [[File:KramnikGrischukOlympiad2012.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Vladimir Kramnik]] and [[Alexander Grischuk]] playing for Russia]] The open section of the tournament was contested by 157 teams representing 152 nations. Turkey, as host nation, had three teams, whilst the [[International Braille Chess Association]] (IBCA), the International Physically Disabled Chess Association (IPCA), and the International Committee of Silent Chess (ICSC) each provided one team.[http://www.chessvibes.com/reports/istanbul-olympiad-preview-who-will-play-and-who-wont Olympiad preview], Chessvibes.com, 22 August 2012.[http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=8422 2012 Istanbul Chess Olympiad preview], [[ChessBase]], 21 August 2012. [[Armenia]], led by world number 2 [[Levon Aronian]], won their third title after previously winning the event in [[37th Chess Olympiad|2006]] and [[38th Chess Olympiad|2008]]. The [[Russia]]n team were once again the clear favourites before the Olympiad but failed to win the gold for the fifth consecutive time and occupied the second place, while the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] team as a titleholder finished in the third place. Three teams, China, Armenia and Russia, were tied on the top of the standings before the last round of the event with China winning the tie-breaker. But in that final round the Chinese players had to play against the Ukraine, led by [[Vassily Ivanchuk]], while Armenians played against [[Hungary]] and Russia played against [[Germany]]. The Armenians and Russians won their final matches but Ukraine edged the leading [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] team 3–1 preventing them from winning a medal. The Armenian and Russian teams had the same match points in the final standings but the Armenians won the tie-breaker taking their third title. Ukraine, thanks to the win in the final round against China, took the bronze medal. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Open event ! # !! Country !! Players !! Average
rating !! MP !! dSB |- | style="background:gold;"|1 || '''{{ARM}}''' || '''[[Levon Aronian|Aronian]], [[Sergei Movsesian|Movsesian]], [[Vladimir Akopian|Akopian]], [[Gabriel Sargissian|Sargissian]], [[Tigran L. Petrosian|Petrosian]]''' || '''2724''' || '''19''' || '''397.0''' |- | style="background:silver;"|2 || {{RUS}} || [[Vladimir Kramnik|Kramnik]], [[Alexander Grischuk|Grischuk]], [[Sergey Karjakin|Karjakin]], [[Evgeny Tomashevsky|Tomashevsky]], [[Dmitry Jakovenko|Jakovenko]] || 2769 || 19 || 388.5 |- | style="background:#c96;"|3 || {{UKR}} || [[Vasyl Ivanchuk|Ivanchuk]], [[Ruslan Ponomariov|Ponomariov]], [[Andrei Volokitin|Volokitin]], [[Pavel Eljanov|Eljanov]], [[Olexandr Moiseenko|Moiseenko]] || 2730 || 18 || |- | 4 || {{CHN}} || [[Wang Hao (chess player)|Wang Hao]], [[Wang Yue]], [[Ding Liren]], [[Bu Xiangzhi]], [[Li Chao (chess player)|Li Chao]] || 2694 || 17 || 390.5 |- | 5 || {{USA}} || [[Hikaru Nakamura|Nakamura]], [[Gata Kamsky|Kamsky]], [[Alexander Onischuk|Onischuk]], [[Varuzhan Akobian|Akobian]], [[Ray Robson|Robson]] || 2702 || 17 || 361.0 |- | 6 || {{NED}} || [[Anish Giri|Giri]], [[Loek van Wely|van Wely]], [[Ivan Sokolov (chess player)|Sokolov]], [[Jan Smeets|Smeets]], [[Daniel Stellwagen|Stellwagen]] || 2682 || 16 || 329.0 |- | 7 || {{VIE}} || [[Lê Quang Liêm]], [[Nguyen Ngoc Truong Son]], [[Nguyen Van Huy]], [[Nguyen Duc Hoa]], [[Dao Thien Hai]] || 2589 || 16 || 313.5 |- | 8 || {{ROM}} || [[Constantin Lupulescu|Lupulescu]], [[Mircea-Emilian Parligras|Parligras]], [[Mihail Marin|Marin]], [[Levente Vajda|Vajda]], [[Vladislav Nevednichy|Nevednichy]] || 2600 || 16 || 310.0 |- | 9 || {{HUN}} || [[Peter Leko|Leko]], [[Zoltan Almasi|Almasi]], [[Judit Polgar|Polgar]], [[Ferenc Berkes|Berkes]], [[Csaba Balogh|Balogh]] || 2708 || 15 || 368.0 |- | 10 || {{AZE}} || [[Teimour Radjabov|Radjabov]], [[Eltaj Safarli|Safarli]], [[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov|Mamedyarov]], [[Rauf Mamedov|Mamedov]], [[Gadir Guseinov|Guseinov]] || 2693 || 15 || 344.0 |} All board prizes were given out according to [[Performance rating (chess)|performance ratings]]. Shakhriyar Mamedyarov on the third board had the best performance of all players in the tournament: * Board 1: {{flagicon|ARM}} [[Levon Aronian]] 2849 * Board 2: {{flagicon|CZE}} [[David Navara]] 2869 * '''Board 3: {{flagicon|AZE}} [[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]] 2880''' * Board 4: {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Vladislav Tkachiev]] 2750 * Reserve: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitry Jakovenko]] 2783 === Women's event === [[File:40OlympiadChess2012sIstambul.jpg|Chess match in the women's event|thumb]] The women's event was contested by 127 teams representing 122 nations. Same as the open event, Turkey had three teams, whilst the International Braille Chess Association (IBCA), the International Physically Disabled Chess Association (IPCA), and the International Committee of Silent Chess (ICSC) each provided one team. [[Russia]] took the gold medal in the women's section to win their second consecutive title. [[People's Republic of China|China]], led by the current World Chess Champion [[Hou Yifan]] took the second place, while [[Ukraine]] finished in third place overall. The medal-winning teams were also the only undefeated teams on the tournament. China and Russia entered the final round against [[Bulgaria]] and [[Kazakhstan]] respectively tied on the first place with China winning the tie-breaker. The Russian team scored an easy win 4–0 against the Kazakh team, while China faced some problems and edged Bulgaria by a minimum winning score of 2.5–1.5. Both teams were tied again in the final standings, but this time it was Russia winning the tie-breaker to secure their second consecutive title. Ukraine won their last match against [[Germany]] 3.5–0.5 and thus won the bronze medal. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Women's event ! # !! Country !! Players !! Average
rating !! MP !! dSB |- | style="background:gold;"|1 || '''{{RUS}}''' || '''[[Tatiana Kosintseva|T. Kosintseva]], [[Valentina Gunina|Gunina]], [[Nadezhda Kosintseva|N. Kosintseva]], [[Alexandra Kosteniuk|Kosteniuk]], [[Natalia Pogonina|Pogonina]]''' || '''2513''' || '''19''' || '''450.0''' |- | style="background:silver;"|2 || {{CHN}} || [[Hou Yifan]], [[Zhao Xue]], [[Ju Wenjun]], [[Huang Qian]], [[Ding Yixin]] || 2531 || 19 || 416.0 |- | style="background:#c96;"|3 || {{UKR}} || [[Kateryna Lahno|Lahno]], [[Mariya Muzychuk|Muzychuk]], [[Natalia Zhukova|Zhukova]], [[Anna Ushenina|Ushenina]], [[Inna Yanovska|Yanovska]] || 2471 || 18 || |- | 4 || {{IND}} || [[Harika Dronavalli|Dronavalli]], [[Eesha Karavade|Karavade]], [[Tania Sachdev|Sachdev]], [[Mary Ann Gomes|Gomes]], [[Soumya Swaminathan|Soumya]] || 2412 || 17 || |- | 5 || {{ROM}} || [[Cristina-Adela Foisor|Foisor]], [[Irina Bulmaga|Bulmaga]], [[Elena-Luminiţa Cosma|Cosma]], [[Alina L'Ami|L'Ami]], [[Mihaela Sandu|Sandu]] || 2377 || 16 || 313.5 |- | 6 || {{ARM}} || [[Elina Danielian|Danielian]], [[Lilit Mkrtchian|Mkrtchian]], [[Lilit Galojan|Galojan]], [[Maria Kursova|Kursova]], [[Anna Hairapetian|Hairapetian]] || 2404 || 16 || 313.0 |- | 7 || {{FRA}} || [[Almira Skripchenko|Skripchenko]], [[Sophie Milliet|Milliet]], [[Nino Maisuradze|Maisuradze]], [[Silvia Collas|Collas]], [[Andreea Bollengier|Bollengier]] || 2350 || 15 || 347.5 |- | 8 || {{GEO}} || [[Nana Dzagnidze|Dzagnidze]], [[Bela Khotenashvili|Khotenashvili]], [[Lela Javakhishvili|Javakhishvili]], [[Nino Khurtsidze|Khurtsidze]], [[Nino Batsiashvili|Batsiashvili]] || 2390 || 15 || 344.0 |- | 9 || {{IRN}} || [[Atousa Pourkashiyan|Pourkashiyan]], [[Sarasadat Khademalsharieh|Khademalsharieh]], [[Mitra Hejazipour|Hejazipour]], [[Ghazal Hakimifard|Hakimifard]], [[Shayesteh Ghaderpour|Ghaderpour]] || 2267 || 15 || 339.0 |- | 10 || {{USA}} || [[Anna Zatonskih|Zatonskih]], [[Irina Krush|Krush]], [[Sabina Foisor|Foisor]], [[Rusudan Goletiani|Goletiani]], [[Tatev Abrahamyan|Abrahamyan]] || 2419 || 15 || 326.0 |} All board prizes were given out according to [[Performance rating (chess)|performance ratings]]. Nadezhda Kosintseva on third board had the best performance of all players in the tournament: * Board 1: {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Hou Yifan]] 2645 * Board 2: {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Zhao Xue]] 2574 * '''Board 3: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Nadezhda Kosintseva]] 2693''' * Board 4: {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Huang Qian]] 2547 * Reserve: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Natalia Pogonina]] 2487 === Gaprindashvili Trophy === The [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] Trophy is awarded to the nation that has the highest total number of match points in the open and women's divisions combined. Where two or more teams are tied, they are ordered by the same tie breakers as in the two separate events. The trophy, named after the former women's World Champion (1961–78), was created by FIDE in 1997. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! # ! Team ! MP ! dSB |- | style="background:gold;"| '''1''' | '''{{RUS}}''' | '''38''' | |- | style="background:silver;"| 2 | {{CHN}} | 36 | 806.5 |- | style="background:#c96;"| 3 | {{UKR}} | 36 | 781.5 |} == Controversies == On 24 November 2010, ''[[New York Times]]'' published an article concerning the possibilities that the [[Turkish Chess Federation]] has paid the voters amount of $120,000 in order to win the bids to organize the Olympiad. In the financial report published on the official website of the Turkish Chess Federation there was a footnote, which translated into English points on the allocation of these costs for stand, souvenirs, lobbying activities, as well as accommodation, transportation and food for some of the FIDE delegates to vote for the city.[http://www.chessdom.com/news-2010/chess-olympiad-2012-scandal Chess Olympiad 2012 sparkles discussion – NY Times article], Chessdom.com. The official answer of the Turkish Chess Federation denied the claim and mentioned that the sum spent is not very big when bidding to host an Olympiad. It was also clarified in the response that the costs were allocated to pay for the Turkish delegates at the FIDE Congress in [[Dresden]], and the expenses documented by invoices testify that no money was given to any of the FIDE delegates and none of the expenses were reimbursed. In June 2012, [[Ali Nihat Yazıcı]], President of the Turkish Chess Federation, announced that no arbiters from [[Germany]], [[England]], [[France]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Switzerland]], [[Ukraine]] and the [[United States]] would be accepted for the event because of the involvement of those countries in launching or supporting court cases against FIDE, causing financial problems and a loss of distributable income for worldwide chess development. A few days later, the [[English Chess Federation]] sent a protest letter to FIDE, which was later co-signed by the other federations who announced their support. Russian journalist Evgeny Surov was denied accreditation and was not even allowed to enter the venue as a spectator. This led to protests by the Russian Chess Federation[http://www.chessvibes.com/reports/russian-chess-federation-supports-surov-with-open-letter Russian Chess Federation supports Surov with open letter], Chessvibes.com, 30. August 2012 and more than 40 top players.[http://www.chessvibes.com/reports/top-players-sign-open-letter-supporting-russian-journalist Top players sign open letter supporting Russian journalist], Chessvibes.com, 5. September 2012 ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Chess Olympiads}} [[Category:Chess Olympiads]] [[Category:Women's Chess Olympiads]] [[Category:Chess in Turkey|Olympiads 2012]] [[Category:Sport in Istanbul]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by Turkey]] [[Category:2012 in chess]] [[Category:2012 in Turkish sport]] [[Category:2010s in Istanbul]]

Bryant Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Lakeland, Florida]] that is currently home to [[Lakeland Senior High School (Florida)|Lakeland High School]] athletics and the [[Lakeland Tropics]] soccer team of the [[Premier Development League]]{{cite web |url=http://www.lakelandtropics.com/news/tropics-sliwa-as-coach-will-play-at-bryant-stadium |title=Tropics will play at Bryant Stadium; Dr. Panagiotis Iakovidis is majority owner |publisher=LakelandTropics.com |date=February 7, 2017 |accessdate=January 11, 2018}}. It is named for Thomas W. Bryant, a Lakeland native lawyer, legislator, and donor to the [[University of Florida]].{{cite web |url=http://lakelandfootball.com/bryant-stadium/ |title=Bryant Stadium |publisher=LakelandFootball.com |date= |accessdate=January 11, 2018}} Bryant Stadium is just to the north of [[Henley Field]]. In August 2017, [[Polk County Public Schools]] purchased Bryant Stadium from the City of Lakeland at a cost of $1.2 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.theledger.com/news/20170822/polk-school-board-agrees-to-buy-bryant-stadium-for-12-million |title=Polk School Board agrees to buy Bryant Stadium for $1.2 million |publisher=''[[The Ledger]]'' |date=August 22, 2017 |accessdate=January 11, 2018}} ==External links== * [http://lakelandfootball.com/bryant-stadium/ Stadium page at LakelandFootball.com] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Premier Development League stadiums}} [[Category:Soccer venues in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lakeland, Florida]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:1941 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1941]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{About|the founding home of the Philadelphia Athletics}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Columbia Park | nickname = | image = Columbia Park Philadelphia.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Columbia Park in 1907. | location = 2900 Cecil B. Moore Avenue
[[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] 19121 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1900 | opened = April 26, 1901 | closed = October 3, 1908 | demolished = 1912 | owner = [[Philadelphia Athletics]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = US$35,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|35000|1901}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Philadelphia Athletics]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (1901–1908)
[[Philadelphia Giants]] (Independent) (1902–1908)
[[Philadelphia Athletics (NFL)|Philadelphia Athletics]] ([[National Football League (1902)|NFL]]) (1902) | seating_capacity = 9,500 (1901)
13,600 (1905) | dimensions = '''Left Field''' – 340 ft
'''Left Center''' – 392 ft
'''Deep Left Center''' – 440 ft
'''Center Field''' – 396 ft
'''Right Center''' – 323 ft
'''Right Field''' – 280 ft }} '''Columbia Park''' or '''Columbia Avenue Grounds''' was a [[baseball park]] in [[Philadelphia]]. It was built in 1901 as the first home of the [[Philadelphia Athletics]], who played there for eight seasons, including two games of the [[1905 World Series]]. Columbia Park fell into disuse after the Athletics' move in 1909 to the larger [[Shibe Park]], and was demolished in the 1910s. ==Home of the Philadelphia Athletics== Columbia Park was built in 1901 by the [[Philadelphia Athletics]] when the team was established, in the creation of the [[American League]]. The site was a vacant lot on which manager and part-owner [[Connie Mack]] obtained a ten-year lease.{{cite book|last1=Selter|first1=Ronald M.|title=Ballparks of the Deadball Era: A Comprehensive Study of their Dimensions, Configurations, and Effects on Batting, 1901 – 1919|date=2008|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina and London|isbn=978-0-7864-3561-6|page=133}} It occupied the block bordered by 29th Street, Oxford Street, 30th Street, and Columbia Avenue (since renamed Cecil B. Moore Avenue, in honor of the [[Cecil B. Moore|civil rights leader]]). The park was built by contractor James B. Foster {{citation needed|date=August 2017}}, at a cost of $35,000. [[File:OpeningDayColumbia Park.png|thumb|left|A photograph of Columbia Park on opening day, 26 April 1901, which was printed in ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' the following day]] The stadium was very small, and originally had a [[seating capacity]] of only 9,500. This was eventually increased to 13,600 by the addition of bleacher seating in the outfield. During some sold out games, unofficial additional seating could be found on top of the adjoining homes. There was only one dressing room, for the home team; visiting teams had to change at their hotels. Although the ballpark was in Philadelphia's [[Brewerytown, Philadelphia|Brewerytown]] section, beer sales were prohibited. The opening game in Columbia Park was held on April 26, [[1901 Philadelphia Athletics season|1901]], after the first two games were rained out. The Athletics played the [[history of the Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] in front of an overflow crowd of 10,524, with some fans standing on the outfield walls and the roofs of nearby houses. The Athletics lost 5-1, despite three hits by [[second baseman]] [[Nap Lajoie]].{{cite news|title=Carrick, All to the Good, Fools The Athletic Hitters|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=27 April 1901}} [[File:Conference on the field at the Columbia Avenue Grounds, 1905 World Series.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Conference on the field during a [[1905 World Series]] game at Columbia Park.]] ===World Series=== During their tenure at Columbia Park, the Athletics won the [[list of American League pennant winners|American League pennant]] twice. The first time was in 1902, before the institution of the modern [[World Series]]. Three years later the Athletics won again and faced the [[New York Giants (baseball team)|New York Giants]] in the [[1905 World Series]]. The Giants won the series 4 games to 1. Games 1 and 3 were held at Columbia Park. Both were shutout victories for Giants future [[Baseball Hall of Fame|hall of famer]] [[Christy Mathewson]].{{cite book|last1=Ritter|first1=Lawrence|title=Lost Ballparks: A Celebration of Baseball's Legendary Fields|date=1992|publisher=Viking Studio Books|location=New York|isbn=0140234225|page=178}} ==Other teams== The Athletics leased the ballpark to the independent [[Negro Leagues|Negro League]] club the [[Philadelphia Giants]]. The Giants played at the ballpark while the Athletics were on the road. The Giants were the first club to play night baseball in Philadelphia when they played under portable lights on June 4, 1902. The [[Philadelphia Phillies]] temporarily called Columbia Park home in [[1903 Philadelphia Phillies season|1903]] while [[Baker Bowl]] was repaired after a balcony collapse on August 8, 1903.{{cite book |title=Connie Mack and the Early Years of Baseball |last=Macht |first=Norman L. |authorlink= |author2=Connie Mack, III |year=2007 |publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]] |location= |isbn=0-8032-3263-2 |page=316 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZvAWd-Aq5UMC&pg=PA315&dq=Phillies+Athletics+city+series#PPA316,M1 |accessdate=2009-05-22 }} The Phillies played sixteen games at Columbia Park in August and September 1903.{{cite web | title=Alternate Site Games Since 1901 | url=http://www.retrosheet.org/neutral.htm | work= | publisher=[[Retrosheet]]| accessdate=2009-05-22}} The stadium also briefly served as the home of the [[Philadelphia Athletics (NFL)|Philadelphia Athletics football club]], before the team folded in 1902. ==Disuse and demolition== The final game played at the park took place on October 3, [[1908 Philadelphia Athletics season|1908]]; the visiting [[Boston Americans]] defeated the Athletics 5-0 in the second game of a doubleheader. The lack of seating at Columbia Park was the main reason the Athletics left for Shibe Park. The sod from Columbia Park was transplanted to [[Shibe Park]] after the 1908 season.{{cite book |title=Shoeless Joe and Ragtime Baseball|last=Frommer |first=Harvey |authorlink= |year=2008|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]] |location= |isbn=0-8032-1862-1 |page=23 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=B_FXGNCmieAC&pg=PA23&dq=%22Columbia+Park%22+Athletics|accessdate=2009-05-22 }} After the Athletics left, the park was almost entirely abandoned. Columbia Park was eventually demolished in the 1910s to make way for new homes. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Columbia Park}} *[http://philadelphiaathletics.org/columbia-park-was-the-first-home-of-the-athletics/ PhiladelphiaAthletics.org: Columbia Park was the first home of the Athletics] *[http://www.ballparks.com/baseball/american/columb.htm Ballparks.com: Columbia Park] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the [[Philadelphia Athletics]] | years = [[1901 in baseball|1901]] – [[1908 in baseball|1908]] | before = first ballpark | after = [[Shibe Park]] }} {{S-end}} {{Oakland Athletics}} {{NFL (1902)}} {{Coord|39|58|52|N|75|10|58|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Wooden baseball parks}} {{Portal|Philadelphia}} [[Category:Defunct Major League Baseball venues]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Philadelphia Athletics stadiums]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:National Football League (1902) venues]] [[Category:1901 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1901]] [[Category:1910s disestablishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1912]]

It was opened in 2005 and has a capacity of 15,000 people.{{cite web|author=Taiwan |url=http://www.touristlink.com/taiwan/douliou/overview.html |title=Douliou Taiwan Tourist Information |publisher=Touristlink.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-25}} ==See also== {{commons category|Douliu Baseball Stadium}} *[[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Baseball venues in Taiwan}} {{Coord|23.7177825|120.536027|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Taiwan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Yunlin County]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Taiwan]] {{Taiwan-sports-venue-stub}} {{Asia-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox venue | name = Edgerton Park Arena | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former names = | location = | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1892|10|18}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1956 | demolished = | owner = [[Rochester, New York|City of Rochester]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = Basketball: 4,200
Hockey: 3,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Rochester Royals]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1945–55)
[[Rochester Cardinals]] ([[International Hockey League (1929–36)|IHL]]) (1935-36) | embedded = | publictransit = [[Rochester Subway]] ([[Edgerton Park (RIRTR station)|Edgerton Park]]) }} '''Edgerton Park Arena''' was an indoor [[arena]] in [[Rochester, New York]]. The building was originally constructed in 1892 as the drill hall for a training school for delinquent boys. When the school moved early in the 20th century, the building was turned into an indoor sports arena and exhibition hall. An artificial ice-making system was installed in 1935. The first professional team to use the building was the [[Rochester Cardinals]] hockey team in 1935-36. The Cardinals played in the International Hockey League and were a farm team of the [[New York Americans]] of the National Hockey League. Rochester could have been a charter member of the International-American Hockey League which formed in the summer of 1936 upon the merger of the IHL and the Canadian-American Hockey Leagues. However, the Cardinals went into receivership before the end of the 1935–36 season and no suitable owner could be found to operate the team. Also, the arena sat only 3,500 for hockey and officials of the new league wanted a minimum capacity of 5,000. The City of Rochester, the arena's owners, refused to expand the building. This refusal to expand the building meant Rochester had to wait until the Community War Memorial Arena (now [[Blue Cross Arena at the War Memorial]]) opened in 1955 to join the American Hockey League. Rochester was awarded a new franchise in the American Hockey League in 1956 after Pittsburgh withdrew. The [[Rochester Americans]] began play in the 1956-57 season. In 1940 the International-American Hockey League changed its name to the American Hockey League. The AHL is now the premier minor league in professional hockey. Edgerton Park Arena was the primary home of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[Rochester Royals]] from 1945 to 1955. The Royals moved into the new Rochester Community War Memorial for the 1955–56 NBA season. But because of periodic scheduling conflicts and the two-month-long 1956 American Bowling Congress Finals scheduled for the War Memorial, the Royals returned to the Arena to play several games during the 1955–56 season. It also hosted performances by the [[Glenn Miller Orchestra]] and cowboy star [[Gene Autry]] in the 1940s. The arena held 4,200 people for basketball. The building was demolished in the late 1950s. ==External links== {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the
[[Rochester Royals]] | years = 1945 – 1955 | before = first arena | after = [[Rochester War Memorial]] }} {{End}} {{Coord|43.1727|-77.6344|display=title|type:landmark_region:US-NY}} {{Sacramento Kings}} {{Rochester Sports}} [[Category:Sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Former National Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Defunct indoor arenas in New York (state)]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Rochester, New York]] [[Category:1892 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1892]] [[Category:1956 disestablishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1956]] [[Category:Defunct basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in New York (state)]] {{NewYork-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = GD Amarantes | nickname = | image = | fullname = Grêmio Desportivo Amarantes | founded = 1936 | ground = [[Estádio Municipal Aderito Sena]],
[[Mindelo]], [[Cape Verde]] | capacity = 5,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[São Vicente Second Division]] | season = [[2016–17 São Vicente Island League#Second Division|2016-17]] | position = 3rd | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=|body1=|rightarm1=|shorts1=|socks1= | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=|body2=|rightarm2=|shorts2=|socks2= }} '''Grêmio Desportivo Amarante''' or '''Amarantes''' ([[Capeverdean Crioulo]], [[ALUPEC]] or [[ALUPEK]]: ''GD Amarantis'', [[São Vicente Crioulo|São Vicente]]: ''GD Amarantes'') is a [[Association football|football]] club that had played in the Premier division and plays in the [[São Vicente Island League]] in [[Cape Verde]].[http://www.becv.org/vitrina-associados/gremio-desportivo-amarante Gremio Desportivo Amarante - Commercial Chamber of Northern Cape Verde] {{pt icon}} It is based in the city of [[Mindelo]] in the island of [[São Vicente, Cape Verde|São Vicente]] . Its logo has a navy blue colored shield with the short name GDA from left to right and bottom and a brown eagle carrying a brown football reading "always ahead" (Portuguese: sempre a frente). As there is a club named [[Amarante F.C.|Amarante]] in Portugal based in Amarante, the club has no affiliation with that club as its logo is different. ==History== The club was founded in 1936 and is the island's fourth oldest club in São Vicente. Amarante has four regional titles won. It was the second club to win a title in the regionals. Académica was even in the number of titles from 1953 to 1964, with the exception from 1961 to 1962 where the club had the most number of titles. It had the third most in the region until 1985 when [[FC Derby]] took the position and became fourth in most number of regional titles, their fourth and recent was won in 1999. Since 2012, the title totals are shared with [[Batuque FC|Batuque]]. Amarante celebrated its 50th anniversary in 1986. It is one of a couple of teams that only won one title since independence and was in 1999. The club won five insular titles and once took part in the colonial in 1961 where they lost to [[Sporting Clube da Praia]] and the national in [[1999 Cape Verdean Football Championships|1999]] where they won the only national title. Also at the 1999 national championships, they finished with 13 points, a record stood for two seasons until Fogo's [[Botafogo FC (Cape Verde)|Botafogo]] took it in 2001, they also had 4 wins and 8 goals scored, half were scored in a match against [[Juventude do Sal]] where they won 4-0, one of three matches that was the highest at the national championships that season. At the finals, they faced Fogo's [[Vulcânicos FC|Vulcânicos]] and defeated it 2-0 in the first leg, the second leg was a goal draw. In 2011, the club celebrated its 75th anniversary of its foundation. In the 2015-16 season, Amarante as second placed club in the cup competition lost to Mindelense in the 2015 regional super cup. Amarante won their only regional [[São Vicente Opening Tournament|Association Cup]] title. Amarante finished last place behind Farense and appeared in the regional second division for the first time in January 2017 and became the fourth club after [[Académica do Mindelo]], it started with the Second Division's Association Cup, until then, Amarante was one of five unrelegated clubs in the region. Amarante's final result was 3rd, the level where they will participate again in the Second Division, their second one next season as they were shy of being in the 50/50 zone of ever returning to the Premier Division. In the cup competition, the club reached up to the Semifinals and lost a match and was kicked out from further competition. Amarante played another season in the Second Division on January 28 and made a scoreless goal with Falcões. Amarante struggled for their planned return to the Premier Division as they defeated [[SC Corinthians São Vicente|Corinthians]] 2-0 in their third overall championship meeting. Ponta de Pom recently defeated Amarante and has 8 points, 2 wins and draws, sharing with Corinthians, Amarante scored 8 and conceded 7 which makes it second, a small chance or a return to the Premier Division lost. Amarante defeated Corinthians on March 3 and kept their chance of returning next season. this continued with a two goal draw with Falcões and a goal draw with Corinthians. Amarante is still second, the same results but conceded 12 goals, one more than Falcões. Amarante is struggling for a chance to return to the Premier Division next season as well as Falcões, Corinthians and São Pedro, the least are two promotional matches. They have only two points above fourth placed São Pedro. ===Playoff advances=== GD Amarantes was the 1998/99 season and won the insular title and advanced to the national division. GD Amarantes challenged the Fogo-based team known as [[Vulcânicos]], the first leg was 2-0, the second leg was a tied game and claimed the title over Vulcânicos. It is the only time ever as well as other teams that advanced into the national division. ==Stadium== The club and plays in the [[Estádio Municipal Adérito Sena|Adérito Sena Stadium]] with a capacity of once served up to 4,000, now serves 5,000 after the renovation, it is named after one of the first players of the club Adérito Carvalho da Sena (1905–1970). [[CS Mindelense|Mindelense]], [[FC Derby]], [[Académica do Mindelo]] and [[Batuque FC|Batuque]] are the other major clubs of the city and the island playing in that stadium along with [[GS Castilho]]. revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} '''Hit wicket''' is a method of [[Dismissal (cricket)|dismissal]] in the sport of [[cricket]]. This method of dismissal is governed by Law 35 of the [[Laws of Cricket]]. The striker is out "hit wicket" if, after the bowler has entered his delivery stride and while the ball is in play, his wicket is [[Wicket#Dismissing a batsman|put down]] by his bat or his person.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lords.org/mcc/laws-of-cricket/laws/law-35-hit-wicket/|title=Law 35 - Hit wicket|website=www.lords.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The striker may do this whilst preparing to receive or receiving a delivery or in setting off for his first run after playing the delivery. In simple language, if the striking batsman knocks the bails off the stumps or uproots the stumps, while attempting to hit the ball or take off for a run, he is out hit wicket.
This method is the sixth most common method of dismissal after [[Caught (cricket)|caught]], [[bowled]], [[leg before wicket]], [[run out]] and [[stumped]]. It is significantly rarer than any of these, which constitute the five conventional methods, but still much more common than the other four ([[timed out]], [[obstructing the field]], [[retired out]] and [[hit the ball twice]]), which are extremely rare.
Although a bowler is given credit for the wicket, it is not a method of dismissal that a bowler actively seeks. A batsman may not be given out "hit wicket" if the ball is not actually delivered by the [[Bowler (cricket)|bowler]] or if the delivery is a [[no-ball]].
{{As of|2018|April|3}}, a total of 158 batsmen have been dismissed hit wicket in [[Test cricket]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Batsmen dismissed by hit wicket in Test cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=1;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> 66 batsmen in [[One Day International]]s<ref>{{cite web|title=Batsmen dismissed by hit wicket in One Day International cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=2;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> and 10 in [[Twenty20 International]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Batsmen dismissed by hit wicket in Twenty20 International cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=3;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> In the women's game, 12 players have been dismissed in [[women's Test cricket|Tests]] by hit wicket,<ref>{{cite web|title=Players dismissed by hit wicket in women's Test cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=8;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> six players [[Women's One Day International cricket|women's ODIs]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Players dismissed by hit wicket in women's One Day International cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=9;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> and only one player, [[Marizanne Kapp]] of [[South Africa women's national cricket team|South Africa]], has been dismissed by this method in a [[women's Twenty20 International]] match.<ref>{{cite web|title=Players dismissed by hit wicket in women's Twenty20 International cricket|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=10;dismissal=6;filter=advanced;orderby=start;size=200;template=results;type=batting;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref>
==Notable dismissals== Due to the rarity of this method of dismissal, many occurrences in international cricket are notable.
===Commentary gaffe=== On 9 August 1991, during a match between [[English cricket team|England]] and the [[West Indian cricket team|West Indies]] at [[the Oval]], [[Ian Botham]] fell over his stumps whilst attempting to hook [[Curtly Ambrose]] and so was dismissed "hit wicket". Later in the day, [[Brian Johnston]] of BBC Radio's ''[[Test Match Special]]'' read out the details of the scorecard as normal. When he came to Botham's dismissal, his fellow presenter [[Jonathan Agnew]] commented that Botham 'just didn't quite get his leg over'. This was a [[double entendre]] meaning that he was not able to avoid hitting his stumps by getting his leg higher than the stumps, and also a reference to sex. Johnston slowly started laughing until he could commentate no more, leaving about a minute of broadcasting being just him in a fit of giggles.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/test_match_special/presenter_profiles/2976173.stm BBC Sport] Brian Johnston and Jonathan Agnew of BBC radio's ''Test Match Special'' discussing Ian Botham's dismissal 'Hit wicket'.</ref>
===Disintegrating bat=== In the first innings of the 3rd Test in the [[Australian cricket team in England in 1921|1921 Ashes series]], at [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]], [[Andy Ducat]], playing in his only Test for England, fended at a fast ball bowled by [[Australian cricket team|Australia]]'s [[Ted McDonald]]. Ducat's bat broke, and a splinter flew back and dislodged a bail, the ball being caught behind by a slip fielder. Ducat was given out "caught", although it seems likely that he could also have been given out "hit wicket".<ref>http://www.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1920S/1920-21/ENG_IN_AUS/ENG_AUS_T3_14-20JAN1921.html</ref>
Later in 1921, in the 2nd Test between Australia and [[South African cricket team|South Africa]] at [[Old Wanderers]] in [[Johannesburg]], McDonald dismissed [[Billy Zulch]] in a similar fashion, breaking the batsman's bat so that fragments flew back to dislodge a bail, and Zulch was given out "hit wicket".<ref name=StrangeDismissals/>
After these incidents, the MCC clarified that whole bat must break the wicket for the batsman to be given out "hit wicket". However, effective 1 October 2010, this law has been changed to allow a batsman to be dismissed "hit wicket" if a splinter, or part of his bat, breaks the wicket.<ref>http://www.middlesexchampionship.com/MCC%20Law%20Changes%202011%97Summary%20of%20Changes%20for%20players.pdf</ref>
===Flying gloves=== Playing for [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] against [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] at [[the Oval]] in 1953, [[Alan Revill]]'s hand was hit by a lifting delivery from [[Alec Bedser]]. Revill shook his hand in pain, and his glove flew off, hit the stumps, and dislodged a bail. The umpire considered that Revill was still "playing at the ball", and he was dismissed "hit wicket".<ref name=StrangeDismissals/>
===Falling headgear=== In Test cricket, a number of batsmen have been out "hit wicket" as a result of headgear falling onto the stumps.
In the 2nd Test between Australia and the West Indies at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|MCG]] in 1960–61 (the Test immediately after the famous [[Tied Test]] at [[Brisbane]]), [[Joe Solomon]] was first out in the second innings, following on. Playing back to a [[topspinner]] bowled by [[Richie Benaud]], his cap fell off and dislodged a bail, so he was out "hit wicket".<ref>http://www.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1960S/1960-61/WI_IN_AUS/WI_AUS_T2_30DEC1960-03JAN1961.html</ref><ref>http://www.abc.net.au/calypso/synopsis2.htm</ref> The Australian crowd thought the dismissal was unsporting, and booed their own side.
In Warwickshire's County Championship match against Hampshire at Edgbaston in 1962, [[M. J. K. Smith]] was dismissed when a gust of wind blew his cap on to his wicket.<ref name=StrangeDismissals>http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/231414.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.edgbaston.com/Scorecards/25/25383.html| title= Warwickshire v Hampshire in 1962|publisher=Warwickshire County Cricket Club| access-date=31 March 2018}}</ref>
Two [[Indian cricket team|Indian]] cricketers have been dismissed in a similar fashion – [[Ashok Mankad]] by England's [[Chris Old]] during the 3rd Test at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]] in July 1974,<ref>http://www.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1970S/1974/IND_IN_ENG/IND_ENG_T3_04-08JUL1974.html</ref> and [[Dilip Vengsarkar]] by Australia's [[Jeff Thomson]] during the 1st Test at Brisbane in December 1977.<ref>http://www.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1970S/1977-78/IND_IN_AUS/IND_AUS_T1_02-06DEC1977.html</ref>
In the 3rd [[One Day International]] between [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] and Australia in [[Dunedin]] in February 2000, New Zealand's [[Adam Parore]] had his helmet knocked off by a short-pitched delivery from [[Brett Lee]]. The helmet fell into the stumps, and Parore was also out "hit wicket", causing some disturbance in the crowd.<ref name=StrangeDismissals/><ref>http://aus.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1999-2000/AUS_IN_NZ/SCORECARDS/AUS_NZ_ODI3_23FEB2000.html</ref>
In the 3rd Test between England and West Indies at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]] on 9 June 2007, [[Kevin Pietersen]] was out "hit wicket" when his helmet fell onto the stumps. The bowler was [[Dwayne Bravo]], who bowled a good bouncer that dislodged the helmet. Replays suggested that the force of the ball broke the chinstrap, freeing the lid to strike the stumps.
===Other strange hit wicket dismissals=== [[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]]'s [[Inzamam-ul-Haq]] was also out "hit wicket" in the 3rd Test against England at Headingley on 6 August 2006, as he attempted to sweep England spinner [[Monty Panesar]] and in doing so lost his balance before falling backwards onto his stumps. He attempted to jump over the stumps, but completely fell on top of them.
One of the more bizarre hit wicket dismissals was of [[Sri Lanka national cricket team]] former captain [[Kumar Sangakkara]] in the finals of the triangular ODI Compaq Cup against India at Colombo on 14 September 2009, as he attempted a shot and in the follow through his bat slipped out of his hands, flew backwards in the air and landed on the stumps.
On 1 December 2017, West Indian player [[Sunil Ambris]] became the first player to be dismissed hit wicket on debut, also getting out for a [[Duck (cricket)|golden duck]]. He proceeded to get out the same way in the very next game, becoming the only player to be out this way twice in consecutive games.
==References== {{reflist}} *Gerald Brodribb, ''Next Man In'', Chapter 35, Souvenir Press (1995)
{{Methods of dismissal in cricket}}
[[Category:Cricket laws and regulations]] [[Category:Cricket terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name=Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum |image=Image:IMS HOF Museum.jpg |caption=Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum |pushpin_map =USA Indianapolis |map_caption=Location in Indianapolis |coordinates = {{coord|39.790298|-86.233597|display=inline}} |established=1975 |dissolved= |location=4790 West 16th Street
[[Speedway, Indiana]] 46222 |type=Automotive |visitors=900,000 (2014){{cite web|url=http://issues.ibj.com/ibj/magazines/book-of-lists/2016/|publisher=Indianapolis Business Journal|title=2016 Book of Lists|page=176|accessdate=May 29, 2017}} |director= |curator= |publictransit= |website=[http://www.indyracingmuseum.org/ Official website] }} The '''Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum''' is an automotive museum on the grounds of the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] in [[Speedway, Indiana]], [[United States]], which houses the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame.{{cite news|url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/story/37769728/ims-hall-of-fame-to-add-gordon-stewart|title=IMS Hall of Fame to Add Gordon, Stewart|publisher=Inside Indiana Business|first=Alex|last=Brown|date=March 20, 2018|accessdate=April 2, 2018}}{{Cite web|last=Kelly |first=Paul |title=Davidson, Travers, Coon Comprise 2010 Class For Auto Racing Hall |publisher=[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway|IMS LLC]] |date = 2010-04-28 |url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/news/15926/Davidson__Travers__Coon_Comprise_2010_Class_For_Auto_Racing_Hall | accessdate =2010-04-29}} It is intrinsically linked to the [[Indianapolis 500]] and [[Brickyard 400]], but it also includes exhibits reflecting other forms of [[motorsports]], [[car|passenger cars]], and general automotive history. In 2006, it celebrated its 50th anniversary. The museum foundation possesses several former Indianapolis 500-winning cars, and they are regularly rotated onto the display floor exhibits. The museum is independently owned and operated by the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Foundation, Inc., a registered [[501(c) organization|501(c)(3)]] organization.[http://blog.ims.com/index.php/ask-donald-davidson-my-dad-was-a-riding-mechanic/#.VFD4SMn5cZJ Indianapolis Motor Speedway – Official Blog] The museum dates back to 1956, and moved to the current building in 1976. It is located in the infield of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway race course, and is open year-round, except Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. ==History== [[File:OriginalIMSMuseum.JPG|thumb|Image of the original Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum building]] [[File:Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum - 2015 - Stierch.jpg|thumbnail|Entrance of the museum, 2015]] The first museum at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] was completed April 7, 1956.{{cite news|title =1996 Indianapolis 500 Official Program | publisher =Indianapolis Motor Speedway | date = 1996-05-26}}{{cite news|url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/museum/ |title=Hall of Fame Museum |publisher=IndianapolisMotorSpeedway.com |accessdate=2008-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328133310/http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/museum/ |archivedate=2008-03-28 |df= }}{{cite news | url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/2007-05-02-3092398979_x.htm | title =Museum displays auto racing history | publisher =USAToday.com | date = 2007-05-07 | accessdate = 2008-03-31}} It was located on the southwest corner of the property, outside turn one of the famous oval, at the corner of 16th Street and Georgetown Road. Its exhibits included [[Ray Harroun]]'s [[1911 Indianapolis 500|1911 Indy 500]] winning car, and a handful of other vehicles. Karl Kizer became the first curator. When it opened, it only had six cars. Within a number of years, dozens of collector cars were being donated and acquired. It did not take long for management to realize that the building was of insufficient size. According to Speedway publicist Al Bloemker, by 1961, the museum was seeing an average of 5,000 visitors per week (not including month of May crowds).Fred Agabashian 1961 Interviews In 1975, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway broke ground on a new {{convert|96000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} museum and administration building, located in the infield of the track. The two-story white building was made of Wyoming quartz, and along with the museum, housed office space, the ticket office, a gift shop, and photography department. It officially opened to the public on April 5, 1976, coinciding with the year-long [[United States Bicentennial]] celebration. It officially operated under the name '''Hall of Fame Museum''', but was known colloquially as the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum. The original museum building outside turn one was kept intact, and converted into additional office space. The museum, representing the entire facility, was placed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1975 and designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1987. In the summer of 1993, the original museum building outside of turn one was demolished. In its place a multimillion-dollar administration building was erected.{{cite news|title=Speedway is adding new office building (Part 1)|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7003881//|first=Howard M.|last=Smulevitz|newspaper=The Indianapolis Star|page=27|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|date=June 29, 1993|accessdate=2018-02-15}}{{Open access}}{{cite news|title=Speedway is adding new office building (Part 2)|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7003896//|first=Howard M.|last=Smulevitz|newspaper=The Indianapolis Star|page=29|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|date=June 29, 1993|accessdate=2018-02-15}}{{Open access}} The administrative and ticket offices were moved out of the infield museum building, and relocated to the new admin office. This freed up floor space in the museum for an expanded gift shop and other exhibits. In 1993, the museum parking lot hosted the first "Indy 500 Expo" during race festivities, an outdoor interactive spectator exhibit. In 1995, it was expanded and renamed "Indy 500 FanFest". It was discontinued after 1997, but in recent years, smaller displays sponsored by [[Chevrolet]] have featured former pace cars and other exhibits. In 2016, a revitalization and modernization project began, to expand the museum floor and add interactive displays. In addition, in April 2016, the facility was officially renamed the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum. ==Exhibits== The museum rotates a display of over 75 cars at any given time. Due to considerable space restraints, only a small portion of the total collection can be displayed. Many cars are stored in the invitation-only basement, or at separate off-site facilities. Some of the cars in storage, however, are not restored to display condition. Frequently, cars are sent on loan for display at other museums, historical car shows, parades, and other activities. The collection includes{{Citation|author1=Davidson, Donald |author2=Loscar, Mary Ellen |author3=Bireley, Ellen |author4=Shunck, Steve |title=The Ultimate Indianapolis 500 Winning Car Collection|place=Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum|publisher=Weibel Design Inc. & Brad Hoffner Designs Inc.|year=2011}} over thirty [[Indianapolis 500]] winning cars, various other [[American Championship Car Racing|Indy cars]], and several racing cars from other disciplines. Other items on display include trophies, plaques, racing paraphernalia such as helmets, gloves, and driver's suits. A collection of models, photographs, toys, and paintings are also for view. One display exhibits a timeline of scoring devices. ===Indianapolis 500 winning cars=== [[Image:MarmonWasp.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Ray Harroun|Harroun]]'s 1911-winning [[Marmon Motor Car Company|Marmon]] "Wasp" on display at the museum.]] [[Image:Luyendyk Lola Chevrolet.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The winning cars of [[Arie Luyendyk]] (30), [[Jacques Villeneuve]] (27) and [[Eddie Cheever]] (51) on display at the museum in 2008.]] [[Image:Foyt1977car.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[A. J. Foyt]]'s 1977 winning car]] *[[1911 Indianapolis 500|1911]] [[Marmon Motor Car Company|Marmon]] Wasp (winner of first Indianapolis 500) ([[Ray Harroun]]) *[[1912 Indianapolis 500|1912]] [[National Motor Vehicle Company|National]] ([[Joe Dawson (racecar driver)|Joe Dawson]]) *[[1914 Indianapolis 500|1914]] [[Delage]] ([[René Thomas (auto racing)|Rene Thomas]]) *[[1922 Indianapolis 500|1922]] [[Duesenberg]] (also won 1921 [[French Grand Prix]] at [[24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans]]; painted in 1921 livery) ([[James Anthony Murphy|Jimmy Murphy]]) *[[1925 Indianapolis 500|1925]]/[[1927 Indianapolis 500|1927]] [[Duesenberg]] (driven by [[Peter DePaolo]] in 1925, and by [[George Souders]] in 1927) *[[1928 Indianapolis 500|1928]] [[Harry Miller (auto racing)|Miller]] ([[Louis Meyer]]) *[[1932 Indianapolis 500|1932]] Miller-Hartz ([[Fred Frame]]) *[[1939 Indianapolis 500|1939]]–[[1940 Indianapolis 500|1940]] Boyle Special Maserati (back-to-back winner) (driven both years by [[Wilbur Shaw]]){{HAER |survey=IN-112 |id=in0543 |title=1938 Maserati 8.C.T.F., Indianapolis, Marion County, IN |photos=37 |color=4 |data=23 |cap=2}} *[[1941 Indianapolis 500|1941]] Noc-Out Hose Clamp Special ([[Floyd Davis]]/[[Mauri Rose]]) *[[1946 Indianapolis 500|1946]] Thorne Engineering (first race under [[Tony Hulman|Hulman]] ownership) ([[George Robson (racing driver)|George Robson]]) *[[1947 Indianapolis 500|1947]]–[[1948 Indianapolis 500|1948]] Blue Crown Spark Plug Special (back-to-back winner) (driven both years by [[Mauri Rose]]) *[[1950 Indianapolis 500|1950]] Wynn's Offy ([[Johnnie Parsons]]) *[[1951 Indianapolis 500|1951]] Belanger Special ([[Lee Wallard]]) *[[1953 Indianapolis 500|1953]]–[[1954 Indianapolis 500|1954]] Fuel Injection Offy (back-to-back winner) ([[Bill Vukovich]]) *[[1955 Indianapolis 500|1955]] John Zink Offy ([[Bob Sweikert]]) *[[1957 Indianapolis 500|1957]]–[[1958 Indianapolis 500|1958]] Belond Special Offy (back-to-back winner) (Driven by [[Sam Hanks]] in 1957, and [[Jimmy Bryan]] in 1958) *[[1960 Indianapolis 500|1960]] Ken Paul Special (replica) ([[Jim Rathmann]]) *[[1961 Indianapolis 500|1961]] Bowes Seal Fast Offy (first of [[A. J. Foyt]]'s four wins) *[[1962 Indianapolis 500|1962]] Leader Card Watson Roadster ([[Rodger Ward]]) *[[1963 Indianapolis 500|1963]] Agajanian Watson Offy (Old Calhoun) ([[Parnelli Jones]]) *[[1964 Indianapolis 500|1964]] Sheraton-Thompson Watson Offy (second of [[A. J. Foyt]]'s four wins) *[[1967 Indianapolis 500|1967]] Sheraton-Thompson Coyote Foyt (third of [[A. J. Foyt]]'s four wins) *[[1968 Indianapolis 500|1968]] Rislone Special Eagle ([[Bobby Unser]]) *[[1969 Indianapolis 500|1969]] STP Hawk Ford (replica)([[Mario Andretti]]) *[[1972 Indianapolis 500|1972]] Sunoco McLaren ([[Mark Donohue]]) *[[1973 Indianapolis 500|1973]] STP Eagle Offy (replica, first win for [[Gordon Johncock]]) *[[1977 Indianapolis 500|1977]] Gilmore Racing Team Coyote/Foyt (fourth of [[A. J. Foyt]]'s four wins) *[[1978 Indianapolis 500|1978]] First National City Traveler's Checks Lola/Cosworth ([[Al Unser|Al Unser, Sr.]]) *[[1980 Indianapolis 500|1980]] Pennzoil Chapparal ([[Johnny Rutherford]]) *[[1982 Indianapolis 500|1982]] STP Wildcat/Cosworth ([[Gordon Johncock]]) *[[1983 Indianapolis 500|1983]] Texaco Star ([[Tom Sneva]]) *[[1988 Indianapolis 500|1988]] Pennzoil Z-7 Special ([[Rick Mears]]; on temporary loan from [[Penske Racing]] in 2008) *[[1990 Indianapolis 500|1990]] Domino's Pizza Hot One Lola/Chevrolet ([[Arie Luyendyk]]) *[[1995 Indianapolis 500|1995]] Player's Ltd. Reynard/Ford Cosworth BX ([[Jacques Villeneuve]]) *[[1998 Indianapolis 500|1998]] Rachel's Potato Chips Dallara/Aurora ([[Eddie Cheever]]) *[[1999 Indianapolis 500|1999]] Powerteam Aurora ([[Kenny Bräck]]; on temporary loan from [[A. J. Foyt Enterprises]]) ===Other Indy cars=== [[Image:1925 Miller Junior Eight.JPG|thumb|right|200px|1925 Miller Junior Eight on display at the museum.]] *[[1912 Indianapolis 500|1912]] [[Fiat]] driven by [[Teddy Tetzlaff]] to second place *[[1925 Indianapolis 500|1925]] Miller Junior Eight *[[1925 Indianapolis 500|1925]] Miller Special *[[1931 Indianapolis 500|1931]] Cummins Diesel driven by [[Dave Evans (driver)|Dave Evans]] (first car to complete the Indianapolis 500 without a pit stop) *[[1935 Indianapolis 500|1935]] Miller-Ford *[[1938 Indianapolis 500|1938]] Bowes Seal Fast Special driven by [[Louis Meyer]] (flipped car during race, and retired) *[[1940 Indianapolis 500|1940]] Sampson Special *[[1948 Indianapolis 500|1948]] [[Alfa Romeo Tipo 308]] driven by [[Johnny Mauro]] *[[1950 Indianapolis 500|1950]] Cummins Diesel Special driven by [[Jimmy Jackson (driver)|Jimmy Jackson]] *1950 Russo-Nichels Special (won the open wheel race at [[Darlington Raceway|Darlington]] by [[Paul Russo]]){{cite news | url =http://www.darlingtonraceway.com/Articles/2009/07/Indianapolis-Motor-Speedway-Hall-Of-Fame-Museum-Sends-Three-Cars-To-Darlington-Historic-Racing-Festi.aspx | title =Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame Museum Sends Three Cars to Darlington Historic Racing Festival | publisher =DarlingtonRaceway.com | date = 2009-07-20 | accessdate = 2009-12-16}} *[[1952 Indianapolis 500|1952]] Ferrari Special *1954 Dean Van Lines Special ([[Jimmy Bryan]]; 2nd-place finisher) *1956 Wolcott Special (driven by [[Len Sutton]], and [[Rodger Ward]] at [[Darlington Raceway|Darlington]]) *1957 Dean Van Lines Special (winner of 1957 [[Race of Two Worlds]]) *1958 Leader Card Monza (winner of 1958 [[Race of Two Worlds]]) *[[1961 Indianapolis 500|1961]] Cooper Climax driven by [[Jack Brabham]], the first car of the European rear-engined revolution (the car in the museum is the back-up car a normal Cooper T53 Grand Prix car and not the T54 that Brabham drove). *[[1963 Indianapolis 500|1963]] Lotus Powered by Ford driven by [[Jim Clark]] *[[1967 Indianapolis 500|1967]] [[STP-Paxton Turbocar]] driven by [[Parnelli Jones]] (on loan from the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[National Museum of American History]]) *[[1976 Indianapolis 500|1976]] Bryant Heating & Cooling Offy driven by [[Janet Guthrie]] during practice. *[[1977 Indianapolis 500|1977]] Bryant Heating & Cooling Lightning/Offy driven by [[Janet Guthrie]], the first female to qualify for the Indy 500. *[[1968 Indianapolis 500|1968]] STP Wedge Lotus/Turbine *1995 [[Reynard Motorsport|Reynard]]/Ford Cosworth XB driven by [[Arie Luyendyk]] (set current [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway|IMS]] track record in [[1996 Indianapolis 500|1996]]) *[[2005 Indianapolis 500|2005]] [[Panoz]]/[[Honda]] driven by [[Danica Patrick]], the first female driver to lead a lap during the Indianapolis 500 ===Passenger cars=== [[Image:Stewart SF02.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Rubens Barrichello]]'s SF02 on display at the museum.]] [[File:Sidcollinsmuseum.JPG|thumb|[[Sid Collins]] exhibit]] [[File:PPGTrophyBrickyard400.JPG|thumb|PPG Trophy for the Brickyard 400]] [[File:IMSMuseumBasement.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the basement at the IMS Museum.]] [[File:IMSMuseumNorthWing.jpg|thumb|North wing.]] *At least one [[List of Indianapolis 500 pace cars|Indy 500 pace car]] from 1911, 1930, 1964, 1966, and 1975–2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.indy500.com/news/story.php?story_id=6607|title=Indy 500 Pace Car Reunion Bringing Classic Autos To IMS This Weekend|publisher=Indy500.com|date=2006-05-18|accessdate=2008-04-14}} *1886 [[Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft|Daimler]] "Motor Carriage" *1886 [[Benz Patent Motorwagen]] *1903 [[Premier Motor Manufacturing Company|Premier]] *1903 [[Premier Motor Manufacturing Company|Premier]] Special owned by [[Carl Fisher]] *1908 Richmond Surrey *1909 [[Haynes Automobile Company|Haynes]] *1911 [[Cole Motor Car Company|Cole]] 30 *1914 [[Marmon Motor Car Company|Marmon]] roadster *1925 [[McFarlan Automobile|McFarlan]] TV6 passenger roadster. *1935 Duesenberg Model JN four-door convertible passenger car ===Other race cars=== *A [[NASCAR]] [[Sprint Cup Series|Winston Cup]] stock car driven and donated by [[Richard Petty]] in 1993. *A [[Sprint car racing|sprint car]] driven by [[A. J. Foyt]] and [[George Snider]] *2007 [[Allstate 400 at the Brickyard]] winning car driven by [[Tony Stewart]] *1998 [[Stewart SF02]]-Ford Formula One car *1991 [[Benetton B191]]B-Ford Formula One car *[[1965 24 Hours of Le Mans|1965 Le Mans]]-winning Ferrari 250 LM. *1964 Hussein 1/Dodge Zerex Special driven by [[A. J. Foyt]] *1961 [[Maserati Tipo 61|Birdcage Maserati]] *1957 SSI [[Chevrolet Corvette C1|Corvette]] *1954–55 [[Mercedes-Benz W196]] Formula One car *1929 [[Bugatti Type 35|Bugatti 35-B]] *1907 [[Itala]] G.P. race car *1906 [[Laurin & Klement]] race car *1906 [[Renault Grand Prix]] *Indy car used during the filming of ''[[Winning]]'' (not restored) *1965 [[Spirit of America (automobile)|Spirit of America]] – Sonic 1 Land Speed Record car ===Trophies=== *Permanent home for the [[Borg-Warner Trophy]] *The Wheeler-Schebler Trophy, which pre-dates the Borg-Warner *Permanent home for the PPG trophy, awarded to the winner of the [[Brickyard 400]] *Historic [[Race of Two Worlds]] trophy *Display case of historic trophies and medals from a broad range of racing events ===Selected exhibits=== *Indianapolis 500 picture wall including winner's portrait and car photograph of [[List of Indianapolis 500 winners|every Indianapolis 500]] winner from 1911 to 2016 *Various paintings and photographs from noteworthy artists *Speedway photography department, including over 4 million images *[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway Radio Network]] exhibit, including antique radio equipment *The [[Tony Hulman]] theatre, showing a short film about the history of the race *An additional admission includes a bus tour of the track *[[Louis Chevrolet]] Memorial ===Special exhibits=== In some years, a special exhibit takes over much or all of the museum floor, commemorating a special event or milestone. Such exhibits are typically on display for an extended period, encompassing the entire month of May, and sometimes throughout the summer. *2011: The Ultimate Indianapolis 500 Winning Car Collection *2016: [[Team Penske]] 50th Anniversary exhibit{{cite news|url=http://www.teampenske.com/news/index.cfm/c/666/52904Team_Penske%27s_50th_Anniversary_Exhibit_Featured_at_IMS|title=Team Penske's 50th Anniversary Exhibit Featured at IMS|publisher=Team Penske|date=February 22, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} *2016: [[Tony Stewart]] exhibit *2017: [[A. J. Foyt]] exhibit{{cite news|url=http://sports.usatoday.com/2017/03/29/ims-museum-to-honor-aj-foyt-with-major-exhibit/|title=IMS Museum to honor A.J. Foyt with major exhibit|publisher=USA Today|first=Joe|last=Tamborello|date=March 29, 2017|accessdate=April 19, 2017}} (40th Anniversary of Foyt's fourth Indy 500 victory) *2018: The Amazing Unsers: celebrating [[Al Unser]], [[Bobby Unser]], [[Al Unser Jr.]], and the rest of the Unser racing family. *2018: Hoosier Thunder: Indiana's Short Track Racing Heritage{{cite news|url=https://indyracingmuseum.org/ims-museum-exhibit-hoosier-thunder-indianas-short-track-heritage-opens-nov-8-dont-miss-the-amazing-unsers-exhibit-closing-oct-28/|title=IMS Museum Exhibit Hoosier Thunder Indianas Short Track Heritage Opens Nov 8|publisher=IMS Museum|date=October 12, 2018|accessdate=October 28, 2018}} ===Basement=== Due to the size of the collection, and space constraints on the display floor, a large portion of the collection is stored in the basement. Some cars are rotated into display, while others remain downstairs permanently, out of view from the public. The basement at the museum is strictly off-limits to the public, and admittance is by invitation only. The contents of the basement collection has become a source of [[folklore]] and mystique, as some extremely rare vehicles are stored there, few visitors are allowed to enter, and photography is strictly forbidden. ===North Wing=== In 2016, the museum display floor was expanded by 6,000 square feet after office space was relocated to another building.[http://www.indystar.com/story/life/2016/05/02/speedway-museum-wants-double-size/83798518/ Speedway museum wants to double in size] The new North Wing is used to display additional cars, and offers a view of a portion of the IMS road course. ==Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame== [[File:IMSHallofFame.JPG|thumb|The Auto Racing Hall of Fame]] The Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame, formerly known as the '''Auto Racing Hall of Fame''', dates back to 1952. It was established and supported by the [[American Automobile Association|AAA]] and [[Ford Foundation]]. It was originally the brainchild of [[Tony Hulman]] who had expressed interest in starting a racing [[hall of fame]] shortly after he purchased the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in 1946. As of 2017, there have been 153 inductees enshrined into the hall. The [[AAA Contest Board|AAA]] dropped out of racing entirely in 1955. After being established for only three years, and after only a handful of historical, "veterans committee" inductees, the hall of fame went dormant. A year later, the first Indianapolis Motor Speedway museum opened its doors. In 1961, Hulman acquired and revived the hall of fame, and incorporated it into the Speedway's museum organization. Candidates can be nominated after at least twenty years from the first date of active participation in professional-level auto racing. A short list of nominees from before 1970, and nominees after 1970 are placed on the ballot. Inductees must receive 75 percent of the votes of a roughly 150-member panel of racing officials, living hall of fame members, and selected media representatives. Participation and accomplishments in the [[Indianapolis 500]] are heavily weighed, but are not the lone factors in consideration. Since 2018, the scope has been expanded to include participants of other events at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway: the [[Brickyard 400]] NASCAR race, which has taken place at IMS from 1994-present, and [[United States Grand Prix#Indianapolis Grand Prix|U.S. Grand Prix]] when [[Formula One]] competed at IMS from 2000-2007. Voting is held annually in the early spring. Beginning in 2017, the announcement of the inductees is made on Founders Day (March 20), the date in which the track was incorporated in 1909. The new members are formally inducted about a week before the race during a special ceremony. There is no set number of inductees for each year, and the number varies annually. Inductees that are deceased are sometimes assigned Speedway historian [[Donald Davidson (historian)|Donald Davidson]] to accept the award in their memory. In 2004, former car owner [[Roger Penske]] accepted the award on behalf of [[Emerson Fittipaldi]], who could not make the trip from [[Brazil]]. In 2010, mechanics Frank Coon and Jim Travers were notably inducted as a pair, as their contributions were largely recognized as mutual and inseparable.{{cite news|url=https://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/events/lpga/news-multimedia/all/2010/04/28/davidson-travers-coon-comprise-2010-class-for-auto-racing-hall?startrow=226|title=Davidson, Travers, Coon Comprise 2010 Class For Auto Racing Hall|publisher=Indianapolis Motor Speedway|first=Paul|last=Kelly|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=April 12, 2018}} The current inductees are summarized below.{{cite news|title =2002 Record Book: Indianapolis 500|publisher=[[Indianapolis Star]] |year = 2002}} The 2018 inductees were [[Jeff Gordon]] and [[Tony Stewart]], the first drivers to be inducted for their Brickyard 400 success.{{cite news|url=https://indyracingmuseum.org/racing-legends-gordon-stewart-elected-to-rebranded-indianapolis-motor-speedway-hall-of-fame/|title=Racing Legends Gordon Stewart Elected to Rebranded Indianapolis Motor Speedway Hall of Fame|publisher=IMS Museum|date=March 20, 2018|accessdate=October 28, 2018}} ===Inductees – Drivers=== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Fred Agabashian]] *[[Johnny Aitken]] *[[Gil Andersen]] *[[Mario Andretti]] *[[Michael Andretti]] *[[Erwin Baker|Erwin "Cannon Ball" Baker]] *[[Henry Banks]] *[[Cliff Bergere]] *[[Tony Bettenhausen]] *[[Joe Boyer]] *[[Jack Brabham]] *[[David L. Bruce-Brown]] *[[Jimmy Bryan]] *[[Bob Burman]] *[[Duane Carter|Duane Carter, Sr.]] *[[Gaston Chevrolet]] *[[Louis Chevrolet]] *[[Jim Clark]] *[[Earl Cooper]] *[[Bill Cummings (racing driver)|Bill Cummings]] *[[Joe Dawson (racecar driver)|Joe Dawson]] *[[Ralph DePalma]] *[[Pete DePaolo]] *[[Mark Donohue]] *[[Cliff Durant]] *[[Harlan Fengler]] *[[Emerson Fittipaldi]] *[[Pat Flaherty (racing driver)|Pat Flaherty]] *[[A. Watson]] *[[Lew Welch]] *Bob Wilke *Ed Winfield *Pat Vidan *John Zink {{div col end}} ==Gallery== Image:Indianapolis-motor-speedway-1985-1.JPG|Indiana state historical marker outside the IMS Hall of Fame Museum Image:Trophy-cabinet-at-Indianapolis-motor-speedway-2.JPG|Trophy cabinet at the Hall of Fame Museum Image:Racing-cars-at-Indianapolis-motor-speedway.JPG|Racing cars at the Hall of Fame Museum Image:Itala Grand Prix Racer.jpg|1907 Itala G.P. race car with 14.75 liter (900 cubic-inch) engine Image:Louischevroletbig.jpg|[[Louis Chevrolet#Louis Chevrolet Memorial|Louis Chevrolet Memorial]] File:AndrettiHawk.jpg|A replica of [[Mario Andretti]]'s Brawner Hawk, the 1969 Indy 500 winner File:Chaparral 2K.jpg|[[Johnny Rutherford]]'s 1980 pole and race-winning Chaparral 2K File:Porsche935Whittington.jpg|[[1979 24 Hours of Le Mans|1979 Le Mans]] winning Porsche 935 File:LogoatIMSMuseum.JPG|[[Terrazzo]] floor logo File:BobbyRahal1986Helmet.JPG|Race-worn helmet of 1986 Indianapolis 500 winner Bobby Rahal on display ==See also== *[[List of automobile museums]] *[[Louis Chevrolet#Louis Chevrolet Memorial|Louis Chevrolet Memorial]] that sits outside the museum. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum}} *[https://www.indyracingmuseum.org Official website] {{Indy 500}} {{Museums in Indianapolis}} [[Category:Indianapolis 500]] [[Category:Auto racing museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Halls of fame in Indiana]] [[Category:Automobile museums in Indiana]] [[Category:Sports museums in Indiana]] [[Category:Museums in Marion County, Indiana]] [[Category:International Sports Heritage Association]] [[Category:Museums established in 1956]] [[Category:1956 establishments in Indiana]]
